instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, cycling
threads.message:
so I have this board which came in, with water damage around <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, and everything on the edge, but its just mild, no broken traces or anything, ppbus and pp3v42 is stable, but pp5v, pp3v3, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, is cycling
pp1v05 is shorted,
there's an audible ticking noise when magsafe is conencted, already unplugged fan, but the ticking is still there, around smc area
when I check <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 1.6v, if i fix everything, will this end in pch problem ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, cycling
threads.message: sometimes, the orange light will turn green , and sometimes the orange light will fade away slowly, is this smc problem ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, cycling
threads.message:
If 3V42 is stable and also <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> delivers correct RTC voltage, then all PCH's RTC signals should be good.
Try to fix these first, to avoid wasting time with dead PCH at the end...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, cycling
threads.message: by rtc voltage do you mean only <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> or all the derivative signal ? ppvrtc and pp3v42 is stable.., i have replaced smc, but still same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, cycling
threads.message: You already mentioned <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> (which bad); what about the other three???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, cycling
threads.message: Turn out <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is shorted, I injevt voltage and <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> heat up, changed <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and board turned on.. The question is.. I often encounter low value on this <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>.., how do i differentiate If its the pch or power rail problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, cycling
threads.message: How often do you encounter the resistor on 4 rtc signal gone bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, cycling
threads.message:
I only found bad RTC resistors because of corrosion, or ripped off by some "specialist" (rarelly this).
RTC caps fail sometime; especially in 3208/09 Air boards.

Last two mentioned signals, have lower voltage usually because oh high ohm resistors.
However, must be higher than 2.1V for good high level threshold.
Multimeter input impedance also makes the voltage to drop a bit when test them; especially <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>.
